Does not meet standard: Copies-and-pastes similar code with small changes.
Progressing towards standard: Creates simple functions with predetermined inputs.
Near Standard: Creates functions that that make use of arguments to modify their output.
Meets standard: Creates functions that can handle novel inputs, with logic and error checking to determine outputs.
Exceeds standard: Creates functions that can handle arbitrary input through the use of “…” or S3 classes.

Does not meet standard: Copies-and-pastes similar code several times to repeat identical tasks on different data.
Progressing towards standard: Calls an identical function (even self-made) to repeat a task on different data.
Near Standard: Uses loop style iteration to act on sequences of data.
Meets standard: Uses apply style iteration to act on sequences of data.
Exceeds standard: Can iterate in parallel and justify the overhead costs.

Does not meet standard: Only works with vectors or dataframes.
Code style is inconsistent and lacks appropriate comments.
Progressing towards standard: Code comments explain the general purpose of the code. Indentation is consistent and predictable.
Near Standard: Code comments explain the broad strokes of intended behavior. Files make use of the built-in section headings in R Studio.
Meets standard: Comments explain code step-by-step. All dependencies and parameters are clearly provided and explained at the top of code files.

Does not meet standard: Does not use git for version control.
Progressing towards standard: Uses git for version control on individual projects.
Near Standard: Uses git and GitHub for version control on group work with appropriately sized commits with descriptive commit messages.
Meets standard: Effectively creates and merges branches of appropriate size. No sensitive files are committed.
Exceeds standard: Effectively requests and performs code review on pull requests using GitHub.

Does not meet standard: Does not use project management tools.
Progressing towards standard: Project management is only conducted though messaging, such as on slack.
Near Standard: User the GitHub issue tracker to set milestones, but does not fill out associated metadata such as who is responsible for the issue and when it is due.
Meets standard: Uses the GitHub issue tracker to break down and assign actionable work with all appropriate metadata included.
Exceeds standard: Uses projects KanBan boards to break down tasks into actionable steps, and track their completion.

Meets standard: Vignettes are provided for the major functionalities of the package.
Exceeds standard: A live website is accessible for the package to share resources and vignettes.
